channel.title: The New Yorker December 4, 2023
channel.description: Jennifer Gonnerman on a school shooter and his sister, Stephen Witt on Jensen Huang’s Nvidia, Hua Hsu on the makeup artist Kazu Hiro, and more.

item.title: What Happens to a School Shooter’s Sister?
item.description: Twenty-five years ago, Kristin Kinkel’s brother, Kip, killed their parents and opened fire at their high school. Today, she is close with Kip—and still reckoning with his crimes.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Gonnerman

item.title: How Jensen Huang’s Nvidia Is Powering the A.I. Revolution
item.description: The company’s C.E.O. bet it all on a new kind of chip. Now that Nvidia is one of the biggest companies in the world, what will he do next?
item.dc:creator: Stephen Witt

item.title: How to Play a Nazi
item.description: The German actress Sandra Hüller probes characters with unusual depth. But to portray a Fascist wife, in “The Zone of Interest,” she reversed her usual approach—and withheld her empathy.
item.category: Magazine / Onward and Upward with the Arts
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Mead

item.title: The Makeup Artist Behind Bradley Cooper’s Prosthetic Nose
item.description: In the age of C.G.I., the work of effects artists like Kazu Hiro remains meticulously tactile. “I was sort of his canvas” for “Maestro,” Cooper said.
item.dc:creator: Hua Hsu

item.title: The Forgotten Giant of Yiddish Fiction
item.description: Though his younger brother Isaac Bashevis Singer eventually eclipsed him, Israel Joshua Singer excelled at showing characters buffeted by the tides of history.
item.dc:creator: Adam Kirsch

item.title: Briefly Noted Book Reviews
item.description: “A Shining,” “Brooklyn Crime Novel,” “Klan War,” and “Earlier.”

item.title: Richard Burton, Elizabeth Taylor, and the Dawn of the Celebrity Power Couple
item.description: From Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor to Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce, the first rule of the A-list relationship is clear: It always involves more than two people.
item.dc:creator: Andrew O’Hagan

item.title: Ilana Harris-Babou, Reviewed: The Artist Skewering Wellness Culture
item.description: In “Needy Machines,” Ilana Harris-Babou continues her study of self-improvement, taking on everything from luxury bathrooms to health-care documents.
item.dc:creator: Jackson Arn

item.title: Ridley Scott’s “Napoleon” Cannot Quite Vanquish Its Subject
item.description: Joaquin Phoenix summons a man prowling the battlements of his own brain, but is Napoleon’s life just too big for any one movie?
item.dc:creator: Anthony Lane

item.title: “Hell’s Kitchen” Brings Alicia Keys’s Musical Power to the Public
item.description: The R. & B. titan shares a fictionalized version of her coming of age.
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw

item.title: Has Great Potential! Meet Your A.I. Realtor
item.description: A New York real-estate firm created a chatbot, Maya, to answer all your home-buying questions. (No, you can’t find anything in Tribeca for under a million dollars.)
item.dc:creator: Sheila Yasmin Marikar

item.title: Can’t Tell an A-Frame from a Poo Stance? Try the Encyclopedia of Surfing
item.description: Matt Warshaw, who’s been busy compiling the online repository for a decade, takes a long-awaited surf trip to Fiji (with his silent buddy Marc).
item.dc:creator: Dana Goodyear

item.title: Lola Kirke Walks the Line
item.description: In the back room of an East Village Ukrainian joint, the musician and “Gone Girl” star engages in a boot scoot to her new song “He Says Y’all.”
item.dc:creator: Naaman Zhou

item.title: Mike Johnson’s Vote-Whipping Strategy: Two by Two?
item.description: A creationist offers a tour of a giant pretend Noah’s ark in Kentucky, which stands to earn eighteen million dollars in tax breaks thanks to the new Speaker of the House.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang

item.title: Why Trump’s Trials Should Be on TV
item.description: The conduct of the trials, their fairness, and their possibly damning verdicts will be at the center of the 2024 election. Transparency is crucial.
item.dc:creator: Amy Davidson Sorkin

item.title: Things I’ve Heard Myself Say Aloud to My Kids
item.description: Definitely no energy drink called Bust, created by a TikTok M.M.A. fighter with a blue Lambo. You get Six Quiet Points.
item.dc:creator: Jay Katsir

item.title: Slide Show: New Yorker Cartoons December 4, 2023
item.description: New cartoons from the magazine.

item.title: “Incoming,” by Teju Cole
item.description: Some of us would be captured. Some might even be killed. But not all of us could be captured or killed.
item.dc:creator: Teju Cole

item.title: The Crossword: Thursday, November 23, 2023
item.description: A beginner-friendly puzzle.
item.media:keywords: Crossword, Puzzles, Thursday Crossword, Puzzles & Games
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Reid

item.title: “Refrain,” by Linda Gregerson
item.description: “Is it only / in winter the sky goes white?”
item.dc:creator: Linda Gregerson

item.title: “November,” by Cynthia Zarin
item.description: “Because I knew / I was meant for loneliness, / you were whom I chose to love.”
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Zarin

item.title: April Bloomfield’s Quietly Triumphant Return
item.description: Sailor, in Fort Greene, is a destination restaurant dressed up as a neighborhood spot—which is maybe the best kind of restaurant there is.
item.dc:creator: Helen Rosner

item.title: Pina Bausch’s Enduring “The Rite of Spring”
item.description: Also: Nutcrackers galore, Allison Russell, a Hart Island podcast, and more.

item.title: The Mail
item.description: Letters respond to Michael Luo’s review of a biography of Mitt Romney, Nikhil Krishnan’s review of “Determined,” by Robert M. Sapolsky, and Michael Schulman’s Profile of Ridley Scott.

item.title: Daily Cartoon Slide Show
item.description: Daily Cartoon Slide Show.

item.title: Sergio García Sánchez’s “Ready to Soar”
item.description: The artist discusses rhythm, rigor, and the linguistic capabilities of art.
item.media:keywords: Illustrations, Art, Artists, Dancers, Lincoln Center
item.dc:creator: Françoise Mouly

item.title: Teju Cole on Open-Ended Stories
item.description: The author discusses “Incoming,” his story from the latest issue of the magazine.
item.media:keywords: Fiction, Disable Inline Signup Unit, Photography
item.dc:creator: Deborah Treisman

item.title: Daily Cartoon: Monday, November 27th
item.description: Not-so-gentle parenting advice.
item.dc:creator: Ellis Rosen

item.title: Slide Show: New Yorker Cartoons December 4, 2023
item.description: New cartoons from the magazine.

item.title: Teju Cole Reads “Incoming”
item.description: The author reads his story from the December 4, 2023, issue of the magazine.

item.title: The Crossword: Monday, November 27, 2023
item.description: Figure sometimes depicted holding a pomegranate: four letters.
item.media:keywords: Crossword, Puzzles, Monday Crossword, Puzzles & Games
item.dc:creator: Kameron Austin Collins
